texts.shortText:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form schools on shallow temperate reefs (although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth). Many species change sex as they grow.

The Sand steenbras is relatively small for a sparid, reaching only about 50 cm. It has a fairly elongate body, convex forehead (distinguishing it from the larger, but closely-related white steenbras), a protrusible mouth and small teeth. Colour silvery with a yellowish sheen and with 12–14 vertical dark bands.
Up to 55 cm total length and a mass of up to 1 kg.

Global: Widely distributed from western Europe and Mediterranean down the west coast of Africa and around the coast of South Africa to Mozambique. Also reported from the Red Sea and Oman.

Local/Regional: Namibia to southern Mozambique.

Unlike most species in this family, and as the name suggests, found over sand, rather than rocky reefs. Juveniles in bays and estuaries and in the surf zones of beaches. Adults over sandy bottoms at depth of 10–50 m. Sometimes form large shoals.

In the Mediterranean males mature at a length of about 14 cm and age of 2 years, changing sex to become females at 21–28 cm, when they are aged 4–7 years. Spawns in summer all along the South African coast. Larvae planktonic.

The elongate body shape distinguishes steenbras from most other sparids. The closely-related White steenbras L. lithognathus is much larger (up to 200 cm), has a straight or slightly concave snout and only 7 and larger dark vertical bars on the body.
